XRP Crashed to $ 1.60 ‚Äî But Fundamentals Are Blowing Up. What's Wrong With This Picture?  Dude, I'm staring at $XRP   right now ‚Äî back at a 9-month low. $ 1.60. Meanwhile, the newsfeed is all green: RWA TVL just hit $235M (+11% in 30 days), new licenses rolling out across Europe, treasury prepping for RLUSD scale-up. Ripple's clearly playing chess while everyone else panics.  But price doesn't care. And here's why: XRP's become Bitcoin's hostage. That 0.998 correlation isn't a stat ‚Äî it's a leash. BTC sneezes over Fed noise or US budget drama? XRP dumps first, even though its fundamentals didn't change one bit.  I keep thinking: we're all waiting for H2 and bills like Clarity Act to clear regulatory fog. Institutions already voted with their wallets ‚Äî #ETF   flows don't lie. But the market's living minute-to-minute right now. And as long as it's glued to Bitcoin's mood swings, Ripple's real progress just floats in limbo.  The question isn't whether XRP will rise. It's whether we can stomach this disconnect between actual project momentum and short-term market panic.  Or maybe the market's right ‚Äî and without breaking free from Bitcoin's gravity, even the strongest fundamentals stay trapped on paper?  #XRP  #Ripple  #XRPEFT  $BTC  #BTC

ü•á Gold Just Added 20√ó XRP‚Äôs Market Cap - In One Day  Markets have been wild this week. Gold exploded higher, then snapped back, while crypto barely moved. The contrast is what caught everyone‚Äôs eye - especially when $BTC  and XRP were put side by side with metals.  Here‚Äôs the headline math: gold‚Äôs market value jumped by roughly $2.2T in a single session. That‚Äôs almost 20√ó the entire market cap of $XRP  , which sits near ~$103B. Even Bitcoin, valued around $1.7T, was eclipsed by gold‚Äôs one-day gain.  But this is where scale matters. Gold is massive. A relatively small percentage move in such a huge market turns into trillions on paper. That doesn‚Äôt mean trillions of new money suddenly rushed in - it‚Äôs just how big markets behave.  Crypto works differently. Smaller pools of capital can move prices much faster - up or down. That‚Äôs why silver‚Äôs sharp reversal and crypto‚Äôs quiet reaction tell the same story: headline numbers look dramatic, but they don‚Äôt equal destiny. The math is eye-catching - the context is everything.  #XRP  #XRPEFT   #BTC Price Analysis#

Ripple CTO Emeritus David Schwartz addressed renewed claims linking Jeffrey Epstein to early crypto projects like Ripple, XRP, and Stellar.  His comments followed the resurfacing of a 2014 email involving Blockstream co-founder Austin Hill, which has recently circulated on X after the release of Epstein-related documents by the U.S. Department of Justice.  Reacting to the discussion, Schwartz said he would not be surprised if the controversy was ‚Äújust the tip of a giant iceberg‚Äù. He argued the bigger problem is the mindset behind such claims. The controversy centers on a July 2014 email sent by Austin Hill to Joichi Ito, Jeffrey Epstein, and Reid Hoffman. In the message, Hill argued that Ripple and Jed McCaleb‚Äôs Stellar were ‚Äúbad for the ecosystem‚Äù.  He stressed that investors backing rival chains were ‚Äúbacking two horses in the same race‚Äù. In a separate response, Schwartz directly addressed the speculation, stating that he is unaware of any links between Epstein and XRP, Ripple, or Stellar. He said there is no evidence that anyone at Stellar or Ripple ever met Epstein or worked with individuals closely tied to him. $XRP   Has a 70% Chance to Close February in Green After Rare Monthly Losing Streak.  XRPL developer Bird highlighted XRP‚Äôs fourth consecutive monthly negative close in a post on X. He noted that XRP has not printed five red monthly candles in a row since 2017. Over the past eight years, similar conditions have consistently led to a green monthly close.  Based on past data, Bird said the probability of XRP closing a fifth straight red month sits at roughly 30%, implying a 70% chance that February breaks the streak and finishes higher.  Previous cycles show that prolonged monthly weakness in XRP often signals seller exhaustion. Historically, after three or four consecutive months of losses, the following month often turns green.  For instance, in 2022, XRP closed April, May, and June with losses ranging from 21% to 28.4%, then posted 14.6% gains in July. Later that year, it recorded losses from October to December and posted 20% gains in January 2023.  In 2018, XRP posted losses of 26.9%, 23.8%, 6.77%, and 23% from May to August. By September, it surged 73%. The trend repeated later that year, with losses from October to January, followed by a 1.13% gain in February 2019.  The monthly chart highlights how extended red streaks have often aligned with accumulation phases preceding a relief rally.  While historical probabilities lean bullish, broader market conditions remain a key factor. Bitcoin‚Äôs direction, overall crypto sentiment, and liquidity trends could influence whether XRP follows its historical pattern or deviates from it.  Moreover, in 2015 and 2014, XRP recorded streaks of five and six consecutive monthly losses, respectively, before gains of 43.8% and 37.3%. This suggests that while there is optimism for a rebound in February, XRP‚Äôs price could still close the month in red.  Still, the rarity of the current setup has drawn attention from traders who view February as a pivotal month for XRP‚Äôs medium-term direction.
